summary: In this animated movie, filmmaker Genya Tachibana begins work on a documentary about famed Japanese actress Chiyoko Fujiwara. Now well into old age, Chiyoko has become reclusive and shy about any publicity, but she eventually warms up to Tachibana and starts to relate her life story. As the decades pass, Chiyoko is transformed from a teen with big dreams into a full-blown celebrity, while her cinematic characters span various eras, from ancient Japan to the distant future.

reviews.content: I loved this movie as a teen, so today I re-watched it for the first time. Didn't enjoy it as much as I hoped. If it was a book, I'd say there's nothing keeping you turning the pages. The story is slow-paced and very bare-bones. The only things I like about it are the beautiful art and the blurring lines between fiction/reality or between different identities.

This is an intriguing anime film. Its not so much a film aimed at young kids and I liked the plot concept of travelling through different times in a persons life, to see what they saw and witness events first hand. I thought the old fashioned, video game type music played at times was somehow endearing - it has quite a strong sense of nostalgia. It's not as great as Tokyo Godfathers (it features the same director) but its certainly worth a watch regardless if your into anime films and so I would recommend it, yes.

Satoshi Kon brings his trademark blend of reality and fantasy to the premise of growth and memory, tracing the career and personal longing of an aging actress through a rich variety of settings and in particular reflecting on the relationships that audiences have with film. 

While Millennium Actress is a well-designed and creative film, interweaving the personal and professional experiences of a main character in a way that is both visually vibrant and narratively solid, it feels at time as if it casts too wide a net in its emotional range, hinging key moments on somewhat underdeveloped side character and introducing a range of potential themes only to let a couple feel unfinished. But at its core the film is still an emotionally charged take on emotional evolution, featuring a main character that has fixed upon a seemingly unreachable goal as her internal motivation before coming to terms with her own desires fueling the seemingly ill-fated search for a man she met decades ago, extracting the image of herself on the screen from her own aging self in the process. At a budget of only about $1.2m, it's a wonder that Kon was able to deliver not only visuals of this quality but an exceptional soundtrack to support it. 

I don't think it packs the whallop that Kon's other work does, but there's still plenty to recommend this work to even a casual viewer; the comic relief is used liberally and works surprisingly well. (3.5/5)

Movies are made not only for writers and directors to express themselves,  it also for audiences to see themselves in the shoes of the characters. There are countless times where I imagined myself playing that character from that movie. This is why I absolutely adored this blend of narration by Satoshi Kon. 

It's his 2nd movie, and I can see how masterful he is at mixing two different elements in such elegant and smooth way. The transition between scenes of different movies was phenomenal and dynamic. I love how the interviewer character changed himself into different characters and re-enact the scenes. It's exactly how movies are for audiences.

The heartbreaking story of this movie was also investing. The symbol of the key and her unrelenting love got me pretty sad at the end. 

Overall, I absolutely enjoyed the eye-opening and beautiful storytelling. 8.5-9/10
A beautiful story that is worth to watch. Beautifully animated too.

In terms of animation, Satoshi Kon's direction is the best I've ever seen! "Millenium Actress" is simply wonderful! The highlights are the smooth transitions between different scenarios and the colour palette, especially in the two main sidekicks (the reporter and the camera operator, who are hilarious, each in their own way).  Chiyoko's journey is fantastic. It's simple and impossible at the same time, original, thrilling, and above everything, very immersive; it's almost Amélie Poulain's journey but completely different. And the ending is a punch in the stomach; it's courageous and touches on a theme that always makes me drop some tears. 2001 was amazing for Japanese animation. Alongside Hayao Miyazaki's "Spirited Away", "Millenium Actress" is one of the best animated films of all time.

Original story and directed by Satoshi Kon  with interviewer Genya Tachibana  tracking down an obscure actress Chiyoko Fujiwara to return a missing key she had lost for more than 30 years they both go down to memory lane revaluating her lost love.

I give it 4 stars on the voice acting alone, and watching it again it is a MASTERPIECE but takes some thinking when watching and probably watching it 2X's to get it.  It's a great movie about immature love and how many people, usually girls, get obsessed with the thrill of "the chase" VS real love where you actually know, accept, and unconditionally care about someone.

About the voice acting. NOW (in the 2000s) all the voice actors are extremely annoying with their overdone hyperbole voice acting. Overlyemotional and RIDICULOUS in everything from My Hero Academia to Demon Slayer. It's really quite irritating.

In this movie the voice actors are more natural and restrained. Nice voice acting.

I'm not sure if I'd say it's a another Satoshi Kohn masterpiece as I really like Perfect Blue But it pretty good compared with a unique premise.

GREAT for anyone into making movies as it's about an actress, cameraman, and an interviewer/huge fan. It's about a love, the film industry, and just life.

Big emphasis on immature love and being enthralled with "the chase" VS real love. The main character chases what she wrongly sees as "love" until her death sadly. MOVE ON DUH lol

ooh, meta! But for a performance scholar, well, what's not to love?! The film refuses to disentangle (fictional) reality from (fictional) fiction-making, and that is cool and mind-bending, and sort of, kind of a political history of 20th century Japan, too.

Ever wondered why does a well-told love story always work in every movie regardless of its genre? Be it a shoot-'em-up actioner, a swashbuckling fantasy, an alien-invasion sci-fi or a cowboy western, nothing can prove a constraint to the power of love in cinema. For love thrives in cinema. It has the ability to ground the most wild and fanciful stories in reality because it evokes emotion in such a way the viewer comes to identify with the characters and invest in the story readily. Satoshi Kon captures that notion here to perfection, blurring the logical line between reality and fiction, forcing us to completely rely on what we feel as we're letting the movie wash over us.

"The Key" is a catalyst that opened the flood-gates of memories of the eponymous actress, letting these memories rush out in flashback scenes the two documentarians interviewing Chiyoko are literally pulled into them. The cheekily innovative way of making them intervene in her quasi-fictional stories added a sense of meta and light relief that imbued the film with much needed breeziness. In addition, that made us pry to Chiyoko's both inner and outer feelings throughout her cinematic and love-pursuing journey. That said, Millennium Actress perhaps runs too short to make a lasting impact on me, and the frenetic pace doesn't help either. I'm sure, however, that a rewatch can make me pump my rating up.

"I can't remember!

Not even his face!

I loved him so much.

Now I can't remember his face!"

The story moulds the agonizing feelings of longing in memory vessels that would preserve love so long as youthfulness lasts. But youthfulness withers, allowing memories to fade away. Here comes the struggle that's even harder than the life-time seeking of love: the struggle of desperately trying to hold onto memories of lost love while your aging mind failing you. That's when you even fail to lament your most precious loss! The story here takes a huge metaphysical leap to emphasize the immortality of love and cinema.
Simply one of the best movies Ive ever watched, animated or not.

THIS IS AN ABSOLUTE HIT FOR ME! The pacing of the story is majestic. No words can truly describe this. An absolute classic from Satoshi Kon!

I recommend it!

A genius commentary on celebrity, cinema, and romance.

Satoshi Kon's romance drama anime Millennium Actress (2001) is a daring foray into experimental filmmaking as Kon blends a director making a documentary about a retired reclusive actress' life with her life story told through her filmography. Millennium Actress is basically an anime biopic. Though Kon's actress is made up, her story is practically the life of legendary Japanese actress Setsuko Hara, of Yasujirō Ozu's films Late Spring (1949) and Tokyo Story (1953) fame. 

I found Millennium Actress fascinating and entertaining with Kon's silly surrealist sense of humor, even when I had no idea what was happening. He throws you right into the narrative with no clues or context, but that helps his surreal direction and dreamy tone. It is a romantic film all about the romantic chase, not so much the relationship itself. I think Satoshi Kon's groundbreaking direction alongside his meta framed narrative of her fairy tale life told in a documentary within Kon's actual picture is pretty cool. I just know I'll be thinking about this one for days. In time, I'd say Millennium Actress might rival Satoshi Kon's anime masterpiece Perfect Blue.

Satoshi Kon and Sadayuki Murai's writing is pure art as Kon finds the heart of what makes young girls fall in love. Indeed, Millennium Actress is a romance drama without a real romance, but rather it ruminates on the very concept of love and appreciation of your significant other. It is a brilliant film and an impressive filmmaking achievement. Satoshi Terauchi's editing is the main star here as he splices together numerous film styles with a quick pace for Millennium Actress' brisk 87 minutes. His montage in the finale set to the enthralling theme song, "Run" is astounding editing skill. His cuts are so swift, you may not even notice a scene switched to another setting.

Hisao Shirai's cinematography is beautiful with chaotic wide shots focusing on the lead actress to always keep the audience engaged. I love every close-up and long panning shot during the running segments. Nobutaka Ike's art direction blends old samurai films like Akira Kurosawa with other Japanese movie genres like romance dramas, Godzilla, and sci-fi features. Takeshi Honda's special effects are dazzling with insane animation. Millennium Actress' colorful style that shifts depending on the genre we are seeing is really creative. All the character designs are really great!

Susumu Hirasawa's score is gorgeous with large swells of symphonic orchestration that help you feel emotional about all of these romantic scenes. All the music in Millennium Actress is captivating in every second. It creates an air of excitement for sure. 

Miyoko Shoji's voice as the elderly Chiyoko is very pleasant to hear narrate Millennium Actress. Mami Koyama's voice for the grown up Chiyoko Fujiwara is lovely and endearing. Fumiko Orikasa's voice is adorable as the younger Chiyoko. Shozo Iizuka's voice for the documentary director Genya Tachibana is very friendly and fun. His plump character is quite endearing as he's just a sincere fan of this actress as his subject.

Masaya Onosaka's goofy voice fits cameraman Kyouji Ida very nicely. Showko Tsuda is excellent as the stern and eternally jealous actress Eiko Shimao.

In conclusion, Millennium Actress is a beautiful picture from a visionary director that I really enjoyed. I think most people would like this movie if you just try to understand all the chaotic choices from Satoshi Kon. May he rest in paradise for all his services to the world of anime and directing.

A beautiful animated film that ironically chronicles a brief history of Japanese live-action filmmaking, Millennium Actress tells its story in a very unusual style, and achieves its humor and stark emotion thusly.
This movie literally left me without words. It blew my mind. Satoshi Kon is a genious in making movies of a human mind... This and Perfect Blue are true masterpieces.

This is literally my favorite movie, had me in tears the first time I saw it and it still gets me emotional. The story is about the life and career of Chiyoko Fujiwara, a fictional Japanese actress who is being interviewed by Genya Tachibana and his filming assistant. Genya, a deep admirer of hers, returns a key that she had lost long ago, something that she held close at all times. Seeing the key, she tells Genya what it's for and recalls her incredible life's story and the key to it all. The movie then begins as Genya and his assistant are thrust into every flashback of her life, filming and watching as everything unfolds. As her real life events and the films she starred in unfold before us, events begin to blur together in what can only be described as the interwoven threads of love, time, reincarnation and fate weave together to form a tapestry that is Chiyoko's story and how they are all tied together.

The new Blu-ray version that came out in 2019 was done by a different company than the original 2001 release and is NOT recommended. The translation is poorly done and the subtitles are rife with SERIOUS grammar and spelling errors. I mean it is REALLY BAD! Look for the original DVD 2001 release, it's by far the superior version.

Satoshi Kon's directorial follow-up to Perfect Blue is a somewhat lighter, less enveloping picture. We tail a pair of DIY documentarians, enamored with their subject, as they suss out the location of a reclusive former starlet and entice her to share her life's story. Truth and fiction intertwine in the telling of that particular saga, with personal memoirs stirred into various scenes from her best-loved screen performances. The result is a flighty, dreamlike atmosphere, a general easing in and out of the present that doesn't always follow a linear train of thought. It operates with a soft touch, which matches the understated nature of our aging narrator; smoothly straddling genres and decades en route to a destined meeting with a lost love.

That puts it on common thematic ground with both Perfect Blue and Paprika (Kon's 2006 swan song), which both toyed with perception and the meeting ground between internal and external realities. Millennium Actress, though, approaches the subject with reduced color and vigor, leaving less dangling threads to captivate audiences and fewer cornerstone visual showpieces to linger in their memories.
Loved it, it was trippy in a good way even though it was extremely sad.
Absolutely amazing animation and story telling.

Gorgeous to look at, and a good story.  Perfect camerawork and editing combined with beautiful images.  The story is predictable, but the way it is told is so creative that you almost need the predictability in order to keep up.  Superb film.

This movie blew away all of my expectations for this film. I have never seen anything like it in anime. The way the movie was filmed is crazy, and the animation is a classic well-drawn animation. I decided to see the dub since it was a brand new dubbing. The dubbing was really good too. I loved the story very fresh and different for anime. Even some of the questions I had were answered during the extra scenes with the co-writer and producer of the film. This is an instant classic and one to own to share.
Creative and emotionally evocative film. Well worth your time.
Loved how Fathom Events showed this masterpiece- but not a huge blockbuster. Keep bringing more obscure films like this!
Second Satoshi Kon film seen, did not appeal to me, interesting concept to be explored in media, with adequate execution. Just enjoy the film for what it is, there not much to unbox.

I loved how the film used Chiyoko's roles as an actress to tell the story! The painter being viewed as the metaphor for her drive to be an actress was well done. I think this film needs to be viewed with a careful eye to notice which is reality and which is fiction (the movies Chiyoko was in)...then again, Satoshi Kon did like to make reality and fiction ambiguous.

Describing this fantastic and surreal anime seems nigh impossible without spoiling it, because from top to bottom, beginning to end, the movie is about itself, a multilayered telling of its own telling—hence "from top to bottom, begging to end" is something of a misnomer, as the film in truth has no such easy terminus, but follows rather the shape of a Möbius strip. It is film about the making of a film about the making of a film star told through the films she has made which themselves reflect her life: In effect, such recursion eradicates any semblance of a fourth wall, as you're rarely sure of which reality you're watching, and like the director of the framing documentary, feel yourself implicated in stories as the audience for whom they are performed. At the heart of this ouroboric tangle is a paradigmatic objet a that drives the titular character: Chiyoko holds a key—to what she does not know, but she has promised to return the lost object to its proper place, and so feels compelled to find its missing lock and the man who, in a primal private scene, told her that the key unlocked "the most important thing there is." Perhaps, however, that does not mean any specific, singular keyway, no particular treasure chest or secret chamber to unlock; rather, as Chiyoko acknowledges at the end of her life, the end of her career, the end of her search, the end of the millennium, and the end of the film—which, shot for shot, is also the beginning of the movie—the key, having been lost a second time and returned to her by the director, has "opened the door to [the] memories" that we have just been watching, movies being a medium of remembering moments lost in time but captured in light.
I loved the art style, but disliked the storyline.

Millennium Actress is perhaps one of the all time great anime films. Its an incredibly sincere love letter to cinema and the story of a reclusive actress reliving her glory days of cinema is universally relevant. As a fan of Satoshi Kon, It was a joy to see this film for the first time on big screen and it was one of the most amazing experiences of my life. It is a shame that this film isn't yet out on Blu-Ray or streaming. I highly recommend it.

It was well made and visually enjoyable.  The characters were enjoyable.  My only complaint was that the narrative was hard for me to follow, which might be my fault.  Just the same, I find myself thinking about the movie long after leaving it.
run like a real person please, not that fake girl running that one only does if you've never actually run before.

I came in knowing nothing about the movie. As the plot went by adrenaline rushed in me, several throat knots started to happen, and some fast heart beating went on. From what I've told already you can see that this movie is an excellent physchological thriller. Satoshi Kon was a great director.
love the art style and the story is amazing 10/10 would recommend if you love watching artsy old anime
Beautifully animated, thoughtful, mysterious, funny, and romantic—and with a great musical score!
An awesome film/Anime from 2002 on the big screen...loved it.   So rare that these classics are brought forward that everyone can enjoy.
loved everything about it. cried the whole last half of the movie.
Beautiful film about trying to find meaning in life and love while showing some history on the actress's life and Japanese cinema.
Satoshi Kon is one of my favorite directors ever and this film really goes for the throat, emotionally.
I'm currently writing a letter to the Criterion to add this film to their catalog.  That's how much I love this film.  That and it's very hard to find.
Amazing movie. A modern day buddhist parable. Satoshi Kon's surrealism blends the cerebral with emotional impact.

Millennium Actress is a movie about a TV reporter who is able to get a rare interview with a famous actress who has retired. What it becomes is a fascinating film where the reporter and his cameraman enter her memories and experience them first hand. At the same time all the plot lines of her past movie roles converge on a central theme that link back to a specific event in her life. It’s a non-linear film that can get quite confusing as you are left to question what part of it came from real events in her life, and what part was fiction from her movies. This kind of muddled storytelling is often frustrating for me, because it can be hard to get my bearings and figure out what is happening and how it all fits together. Despite my reservations, I found Millennium Actress to be a magical experience. There’s something enchanting about the way the story unfolds, and seeing it all through the lens of a man who practically worships the main character helped me to become invested. The different films that Chiyoko starred in were a diverse mix so it kept changing the tone as the film progressed. Then, once all the settings were established, they were able to bounce around from one to the next in order to keep things interesting. It all fit together beautifully, and I was fascinated to see how it would all tie together by the end. The resolution is perfect and almost brought me to tears. Millennium Actress is the kind of film that I need to watch multiple times in order to appreciate all the nuance they included in the story, but even the first time through it was a delightful film that I found thoroughly charming. I cannot wait to explore it more.
There are many stories that have blended reality and fantasy together. This is one of the first to try, and succeed in it.

Beautifully animated with lovely cinematography, 'Millennium Actress' is the touching and romantic story of a woman's life and the great love contained within it. Despite being somewhat slow at times, and quite possibly a bit confusing due to the way the switch between her memories as an actress and reality is handled, it is almost impossible not to be sympathetic towards the protagonist and to become invested in her happiness.

Perhaps the greatest anime film ever made, not technically per se, but conceptually unparalleled and unrivaled. No other anime took the notion of film to its logical extreme or rather speculative extreme as Satoshi Kon did in that masterpiece. Cinema becomes the extension of wish-fulfillment, or rather dreams unfulfilled that are reenacted again and again endlessly, in many stories and in many avatars, and each time that ceaseless search for love/imagined experience  fuels more journeys and more wondering, until the boundaries between the two completely dissolve.
An immensely cerebral, emotional, and breath-taking experience.

The other Satoshi Kon masterpiece. In my opinion, this is his most inventive and unique work which is saying something. Here he uses his ability to tell surreal, logic-bending stories for a completely new purpose than you'd expect. It's near perfect.

I was surprised this was made by Satoshi Kon. Its only because its not a subject I thought he would touch on. Its beautiful in the sense that it is multi layered along with subtle tricks done around the subject of foolish love. I am a victim of that myself. I believe Chiyoko wasnt ultimately after that long lost love, but she was after her own innocence at the time of meeting him, afraid of becoming that old hag, afraid of age and dying and finally, afraid to admit she wasted her life chasing a shadow. Tragic

While the story isn't as gripping and fast paced as other Satoshi Kon's work, it is suited to the bitter romance of his heroine. Animation is superb and the feeling of losing yourself in the blur of reality and all the alternate universes of Chiyoko's films is a pleasure you can find only at this director's hand.
I don't know what took me so long to watch this movie. Wow! This movie is awesome.
not half as potent, wonderful or whimsical as Paprika .. neither characters, nor the storyline, nor the insights into life are all that strong. sadly ..
Thought provoking and tragic in all the right ways
While Tokyo Godfathers might be my favorite Satoshi Kon movie, Millennium Actress is, to my mind, his best film
Not as good as Kon's other films I felt. Ultimately tells a fairly trite story.

Featuring a story that's sure to be considered a classic and some intelligent commentary on the ways in which film affects the lives of those that come in contact with it, Millennium Actress is an incredible piece of filmmaking from a director who's imagination seems to know no bounds.
probably contains my favorite film ending of all time

"Millennium Actress" is one of my favourite films of all time. This is why I love Anime. The Japanese are always willing to come up with creative and original storylines and to even find new and inventive ways to tell their stories. "Millennium Actress" is no exception. The way the flash-back scenes transition from one point in time to the next is really well done, the main character Chiyoko is nicely developed and fleshed out as a three-dimensional character, the humour from the interviewer Genya, in the way he interacts with Chiyoko's past memories, is both hilarious and brilliant in the way it advances the story and the whole structure and ending to the film defies all expectations. It's brilliant; that's the best word to describe it. For me, this is the perfect example of why Japanese animation is severely overlooked here in the Western world and why it deserves much more attention and recognition.
Enchanted by Brilliance and Creativity of this Piece of Art..

Blurring the lines of reality and fiction, as is Satoshi Kons most recognizable trope, is done just often enough not to confuse the viewer, but to provide an enriching experience that has profound messages about film, and an engrossing story to boot.
I liked this considerably more than the other Satoshi Kon movies I've seen so far.

Like the director's previous efforts, this movie is hard to follow with an annoying blurring of reality and fantasy, but unlike 'Paprika' and 'Perfect Blue', it has some emotional moments and the story is much more interesting. Millennium Actress is thanks to those reasons the best film from Satoshi Kon and his most enjoyable, but it is still just a solid film that never makes you care for the characters and is as pretentious as is every film from the director.

The way Kon layers narratives, fictions, and obsessions into a tightly woven, nearly indistinguishable tapestry is clever and well executed. His (apparently) signature cuts between realities are an efficient and artful way to connect and elaborate these ideas. The problem is just that there isn't much here beyond 'clever.' The driving premise is a romance so thin and melodramatic that it shades heavily into obsession, mirrored by the framing filmmaker's obsession with the titular actress. Kon seems so focused on the twists and layers of his plot and how he can move between them and blur them that he doesn't spend much time giving any weight or depth to the characters. That's kind of a shame just because I think the premise isn't inherently unemotional. It's a postmodernist (yay) dissection of the narratives we apply to our lives, and a director as smart as Kon should have been able to apply that theme to someone with a narrative a bit more realistic and compelling.
It's unique narrative structure make this film both a fascinating and confusing anime. All in all, I think the fascination outdoes the confusion, so I say give it a watch.
The best thing ever.
Such a beautiful film, it gripped my heart at times and didn't want to let go.
The reason why I believe anime can be art.

Honestly, the ending made me cry. Secondly, I think this movie is beautiful, I strongly believe this is the best Satoshi Kon film. This film has such a great story and such great animation. This is one of the best anime films of the century! This film is also one of the best films I have ever seen.

A very confusing, sentimental, stylistic animated film about, or at least I think, an actress's search for the man of her dreams. Chiyoko Fujiwara falls for a rebel painter in the early 1930s who is captured by authorities, or so it seems - though difficult to follow due to the confusing narrative and seemingly disjointed plots, and she spends the next fifty years of her life chasing after him. At some point, she may have fallen in love with the search for him more than the man himself, but she persists, encountering tragic turn after tragic turn as the years go by. If after the first half hour, you're still not sure what the hell is going on - what's real and what's symbolic, then don't worry, this, I think, is normal. A wise stylistic and narrative choice by the director? Questionable. But definitely not out of the ordinary to be scratching your head even an hour in - thinking you knew what was going on but being hit with very unusual plot devices and scenarios that don't seem to make the sum of what you were given. I would share this film with devout anime fans and with loved ones on a quiet night.

Animation is dominated by the family friendly market, but animation have also been used to convey more challenging subject matters. Such animated films tackle more complex subjects of war, politics, psychology of a person, and among other that otherwise wouldn't be played down for a family film. Millennium Actress is one of those multi-layered work of animation that will move if you only see the surface, but further analyze everything holds a greater meaning.

Millennium Actress follows a TV interviewer and his cameraman meeting a former actress and travel through her memories and career. The film narrative structure covers an entire actress life told in non-linear flashbacks relentless pursuit for her significant other. In writing that story structure does not sound deep, but in execution cover many subjects it touches on. It's as much a character study as it is a an expression on endlessly pursuing idealized desire. Each flashback involves the actress merging real life memories with those in films she starred in. As such seeing her in various characters and costumes, in different genres set in different eras, like the Samurai films, science fiction, romance dramas, and even monster movies to symbolize a human backdrop of desire. Such desires ranges from wanting to make a difference against your government restrictions, the length of protection of something held precious no matter the danger, and the ever need to a fill a gap. These emotions are relatable, but underneath it emotional study lies a subtle showing of the political policy in each era. We experience life through Japanese occupation of Manchuria through the post war era going in hand merging fiction and reality. All these memories are open to interpretation as well as serving in depth characteristic in understanding our main character. You'll analyze everything from her personality, why she think low of herself, and the true significance of her pursuit. Though this one character does touch on many subjects, but sadly secondary characters are reduced to being archetypes. Either comedic relief or explaining everything the secondary characters just disappear into the background with barely anything to contribute outside of their one picked role.

The animation is primarily minimal in movement with the only time the animation becomes exaggerated is for significant plot point to be highlighted surrealistically. Art direction and technique varied in bringing different eras of Japanese history together and seamlessly transitioning to one era to another. All the backgrounds are detailed and textured. Character design is accordingly appealing, especially the depiction of protagonist Chiyoko through various stages of her life that delineates dignity and purity. Chiyoko itself transcends to some abstract form of ideal love, only unrequited, and therefore allegorically portrayed in her various film roles. Music is electronically assembled with a lot of repetition. It sometimes stands out as a bit overbearing and idiosyncratic, yet considering the nature of theme from the film it does not detract from the overall viewing experience. Voice acting is strong whether in its original Japanese recording which has three voice talent for Chiyoko character in her different age or a dubbed version almost matching the Japanese voice talent.

Millennium Actress is a alternatively rewarding complex film with a vividly detail art style to go with it. Visually stunning, emotionally gripping, and thoughtfully challenging makes Millennium Actress a true work of genius in animation.

WOW. Awesome movie, great storytelling. The director used everything to perfection. We feel for Chiyoko her chase for her lover. The way story blended between the real life and the actress's life in different era's was done masterfully. Loved the music and the humor provided by the supporting cast of Genya. 
"This is a screen trip that actually takes you someplace -- out of the world, around the world and straight to the heart of the world."Bob Campbell
A perfect masterpiece of storytelling, One can see the culture of Japan just by watching this anime flick.

Not only is this better than any Western animation currently out there, but it's better than most live action movies too. This is the story of a director and cynical cameraman who track down a legendary actress who's been a recluse for the last thirty years. As she tells them her life story, fact and fantasy intertwine, and they become sucked into the world of her reminiscences. In this beautifully animated film the characters truly come alive as real people against awesome backdrops set in the past, present and future. It's flawlessly done. But the real treat is the story. A sophisticated plot line that constantly wrong-foots the audience. It is epic while at the same time intimate, and has an emotional climax that's rarely seen in Western films. Beautiful.,

Millennium Actress (???? )
Director: Satoshi kon
Genre: Romance, Animation, Drama
Theme: Historical

Genya Tachibana is a documentary film maker, he searches for Chiyoko who was a great actress but had left acting 30 years ago and disappeared, somehow he tracks down Chiyoko and finds her and asks for her interview, he gives her a key which belongs to her, key had memories attached with Chiyoko's life, Chiyoko tells him about her life journey. Chiyoko is born when an earthquake hits Tokyo in 1923, war was looming in Japan. Young Chiyoko saves a guy who is a painter and revolutionary, he gives her a key. It's a story about how couple of minutes with a revolutionary made her fall in love and how she struggles to reach to him and to give him his key. 

This movie has a deep meaning to it, I loved the plot, animation and actors. The movie is filled with pain, love, and drama. The movie has a deep meaning to it, that no matter how much you chase after someone or something and how hard you try to get it or reach to it, you won't be able to get it if it isn't in your fate.
Are you ready for a never fulfilled love story that goes through a lifetime and beyond ?
Satoshi Kon makes another brilliant and complicated film. It's the anime Inception.

The brilliance and the sophistication of this movie is overlooked mostly because this is an animation, but don't let that fact fool you. This is not a movie for children: in fact, I'm pretty sure that a kid would be bored to tears. The depth of the themes and how they're presented is incredible, from unrequited love, to the fine line between reality and fiction in the life of Chiyoko. It is said that the retirement and isolation is a reference to Setsuko Hara, the actress who plays the "three Norikos" in Yasujirou Ozu's movies, but I don't know much about her to comment on this. The animation is incredible, and so is the music. The plot is very high paced and intense, with transitions from Chiyoko's movies to her life all the time, which can be confusing at first but it doesn't really matter when you realize that it's supposed to be that way, to show how movies in which she acted are in fact a reflection of her pursuit. It uses very cleverly its symbols like the key, the earthquakes, and the old woman with the spinning wheel, all of them serving a purpose like being a motive and an excuse for her chase, or marking important things that happened in her life. This movie is an insight of what life is really about, and what is the meaning of chasing something you want. Chiyoko goes all the way, chasing a ghost from her past, but in reality she is chasing what we all are: a meaning to her existence.

I liked the style and the way the documentary guys went into the memories. I didn;t think it was a very interesting story and didn't really hold you to the film. Still a nice film and i love the animation
Really is confusing until the end. If you stick with this movie, it will reward you!

A richly layered animated drama. It's really not just the story itself that I found so engaging, but how it's told - the use of flashbacks and blending reality with fantasy in a way only anime would make possible.

One of the best anime movies ive ever seen.this film blew me away. it was very original and had a great story. although its not for everyone if you like anime i suggest you check it out. it has my highest recommendation.

Riveting, hilarious and unique.. it's worth a watch even if just sneak-peak.
Millennium Actress is seductively presenting, but at times loses it's direction. The Plot is complex and overlaps to other variations of storyplots. I enjoyed the humur and the choice of characters that spread out from 10 or more year aprt. The Generation gap played a great part in each persons perspective.

Like Paprika (2006), Kon introduces us to a protagonist whom we follow with unfailing loyalty. 'Millennium Actress' is storytelling at its best - a study of disjointed, half-remembered memories that confront some of the more difficult epochs of Japanese history.
This is why I loved woman as the main character in an animation film.
My favourite of Satoshi Kon's work! moving between past and present and fiction and fantasy as only animation can do
Haunting powerful story of enduring love

Satoshi Kon yet again proves he has been one of the most innovative and creative storytellers in animation. This beautiful story of an aging actress telling her story and experiences as an actress within japan is heavily borrowed and adapted in big fish (2003). Kon's film is one of the grandest love letters to historical japanese cinema and style with his actress Chiyoko appearing in several notable genres while simultaneously and seamlessly blending her life's story to each film heroines dialogue and actions, This is a gorgeous movie to look at, creative and really (and successfully) aims for the audiences heart. Wonderful.

I cried.
Satoshi Kon never disappoints.
That is all.
Yeah, the animation might be dated and the love stories (there are two) a bit unrealistic, but what power and what great music.  This is my favorite cartoon.
My favourite anime. The narration technique is just so captivating, and the actress' life unfolds. Thank you for making this film, Satoshi Kon. Rest in peace.

I think the concept of this movie is really cool and it is executed pretty good, my only issue is that I don't have any interest in any of the films this girl was in. To me they all look boring, so when we go to those worlds I don't really care about them. Good animation and storytelling though.
A stunning piece of animated filmaking. I seriously doubt I will see another this good in a long time
Wonderful! Incredibly original, sad and charming. One of the greatest anime films of all time. Plus, the name itself is fun to say!
A beautiful story, if shakily animated and confusingly told.
An entirely understated masterpiece.

Absolutely Loved this movie.  A twisting tale of love, jealousy, and fate.
Dreamworks, I really hope you will release this on Blu-Ray.
Very interesting structure. For some reason, this film reminds me a bit of Citizen Kane, which is obviously a good thing. It works on many levels.
the timeline is awesome! I can't tell which is illusion which is reality

Although the animation is beautiful and the plot summary sounds great, I couldn't help but be annoyed with the protagonist. She was perhaps the most frustrating character I've ever encountered. 

SPOILER: She wastes a lot of time pining and in the end it's just a depressing story that didn't need to be that way. It's like she never grew up and everyone else treats that as some lovely romantic ideal. It's horrible.

not his best work, but definately good enough for me. a very fast paced story constantly shifting between fiction and "reality" (or fiction and metafiction for those who speak litterature lingo - it is an animated film through and throuh) with the scenes morphimng into each other in a way that makes it very interesting to watch if a bit difficult to follow sometimes. sweet :)

Great concept here. a older man doing a doc, tracks down a former star who he admires greatly, there also being a reason, once story she tells begins, about her career start and life before, we get transported in that world as does the man and his asistent, we see her story before big time but it also blends in with roles she has played, and films shes been in. at centre her involvment with a mysterious man she never got to know, and corruption from ones close, her obsession to track him down. in this meanwhile through her films we see plenty of action and fantasy and the old man entering as her saviour as his assistent oddly looks on, the film plays well, and it works on many leviels,

Satoshi Kon's wonderful idiosyncrasies are on full display in his most thematically serious and rich movie. If any of Kon's films should get him into some pantheon of anime greats, this'd be it. Unless The Dream Machine comes along posthumously and knocks socks off.
A great reference to japanese cinema and very enjoyable too!
One of My favorite movies. also my favorite Satoshi Kon films.

I remember when I saw this on TV, and I was absolutely blown away by it. In fact, I got so into this film that every time there was a commercial break, I yelled at the TV. This is also among my favorite romance films because it was so superbly done with its engaging storyline about a documentary crew who interview an old actress and in the process learn her story about falling in love and also go on an adventure through the many films she starred in. It was one crazy ride that was more than worth taking. There was never a boring moment in this film, and I was absolutely captivated by how imaginative and heartbreaking it was.
This is absolutely my most easily favorite movie. The storytelling concept was novel, yes. But what captured me most was the sweeping score and Chiyoko's perpetual search for the Prince of Key.

While I still remain an avid Miyazaki fan, I was quite impressed with this lil anime. I really enjoy the structure of the story-telling, despite the fact that I was a tad confused in the middle, trying to figure out which parts were reality and which were from her movies. It is quite the epic love story.

I can't say enough wonderful things about Satoshi Kon. While Tokyo Godfathers remains my favorite of his works (I consider it one of the best films I've ever seen. Top 10, easily, and maybe even Top 5), this one is fantastic in its own way. I myself really identified with the seamless blend of Chiyoko's 'real' life with her roles; it gets a little hard to differentiate between the true events and her movies, but that of course, is the point. It's all been her life, and those experiences are just as truthful to her as the 'actual' ones. It's really quite beautiful. The characters, as always with Kon, are so interesting and distinct. The plot is engaging and emotional. The visuals are lovely and so much fun since the breadth of Chiyoko's film roles allows them to span from a feudal Japan through the present to a somewhat futuristic era.
Once again, Satoshi Kon skillfully blended reality and imagination into a beautiful movie that is also very touching.
its lovely story...little girl chase her dreams of someone she hardly know.... nice mix between films and realty...

"Millennium Actress is a magnificently different animated film that takes you to an adventure you didn't expect to participate in. It's plot is very well-written and original that I was filled with amazement as the film went on. It's something that when you turn into a live-action film, it will do surprisingly well. The animation is great which makes it more fun to watch. Satoshi Kon rarely fails me and this film is proof because he never strays too far and does his best to perfectly show you the entire film. After watching Millennium Actress, I just felt so damn good. The film is painted with emotion and it almost strangles you but it doesn't hurt. With almost 90 minutes for its running time, I don't think that it is enough because it left me wanting more despite the fact that it is impossible to go on. I feel like it wasn't enough. But, besides that fact, this film is very good. It's definitely worth a watch and even worth watching twice. A very impressive animated film."

Full Review:
http://reverieinwords.blogspot.com/2011/05/millennium-actress-2001.html
Deep creative storytelling through a fictional, yet believable film history.
Although presented in an unusual way, this movie carries a strong emotional story

One of Satoshi Kon's best. Less Perfect Blue and Paprika, more in line with Tokyo Godfathers with an injection of surreality.

The entire cast turns strong performances, as you'd expect in a Kon film - he accepted nothing less. And the actresses who portrayed the titular actress, Chiyoko Fujiwara, over the various stages of her life all performed just as they needed to in order to believably capture the same character in different roles and at different stages of her life. Genya and his cameraman rounded things out.

Where Tokyo Godfathers told a story of people at the very bottom of society, Millennium Actress follows a woman who thrived - though not because she had truly wanted to be an actress - and then withdrew later in life. Where much of Tokyo Godfathers dealt with the suffering characters finding hope, Millennium Actress follows the life of a woman chasing after a shadow that she would likely never catch. Where Tokyo Godfathers, Paprika, and Perfect Blue took place in modern Japan, Millennium Actress spends much of its time in the 1950s and the surrounding decades, the impact of World War II central to Chiyoko's story as she attempts to catch up with the anti-government activist painter whom a brief encounter with dramatically changed her life. Some knowledge of Japanese WWII history can only enrich your experience with the film, understanding exactly who was fighting for what within the country, and to understand what is being shown in the brief firebombing scene - aspects I could see some American viewers being less than well educated about. Where Tokyo Godfathers and Perfect Blue were more grounded in reality and Paprika later focused on the incredible, surrealist landscape of dreams, Millennium Actress crashes the past and conveniently plot-related movie clips together with the present, even taking some meta turns as Genya began to insert himself directly into the scenes from Chiyoko's films. This makes for a story presentation much unlike any I've ever seen before.

Kon's direction was spot on the whole way through, though the initial leap back into a film clip may jar some viewers - you'll grow more accustomed to it as you get a feel for the film's unusual flow. Susumu Hirasawa's original score is excellent, as he can always be counted on in his collaborations with Kon, and in this case, he's unusually restrained with far less energetic electronic songs than usual. Where they do appear, they fit well. Millennium Actress tells a story of a woman of great strength, and it's both happy and sad, as turbulent and challenging a life story as it is. Viewers' mileage will vary with Millennium Actress - as always, in part due to the fact that it's an anime film - but the film is ultimately a testament to the tremendous talent we lost when Satoshi Kon passed away from pancreatic cancer last August. Considering some of the later scenes in this film, I do have to wonder how he faced his final days, outside of the words he left behind.
Y'all are stupid if you missed this movie at the Union tonight. Heartbreakingly brilliant.
nice surreal touches with the man making the documentary about an actresses life being the bit part player throughout it and holding the secret to the lost key that was the link to her one love.

This film engrosses the viewer almost immediately as the opening scene features the main actress about to be launched into space. When one expects to see her in a kimono and is shown that, I could not be more drawn to watch. Millennium Actress is a 2001 animated film from Japan, "The story of an aging movie actress' complicated personal saga unfolds in this sophisticated anime film that deftly blurs memory and make-believe into a meditation on the nature of cinema itself" 

Wow. I can't even begin to describe how emotionally moving this movie made me feel; and putting my love for period films aside, "Millennium Actress" presents a slur of different scenarios from all sorts of Japanese cinema, which confused me at some points yet made perfect sense at the same time. The way each scene progressed from one another, made me doubt the reality of the situation one or two times. But in a sense, for an anime movie to have made me think in such a way, is truly something not worth missing!

If to describe this movie in one sentence, I could probably tell you this: "It's like a mix of Inception, The Notebook and Spirited Away, with its own creative twist that warms the heart."

its at times overwrought, incredible and meanders... but the rest of the time its pretty amazing animation, a discoesque soundtrack and has one of the best knife fights since.. well, whenever. not a romance for the cynical though

On my extremely short list of good anime, this movie is a really beautiful meditation on memories and love.  The character design isn't repetitive, and most of the more annoying anime clichÃ (C)s are absent.  Well worth checking out.
Along with Mind Game, this is my favorite anime film.  It has a unique structure, but you really get emotionally invested in the actress' life.

If Perfect Blue made director Satoshi Kon famous, this movie, Millennium Actress made him the third musketeer of japan animation, along with Miyazaki and Mamoru Oshii. 
The plot and its entire structure is brilliant: an old famous actress, Chiyoko, talks about her entire life for a documentary dedicated to her long career. Chiyoko confuses her life memories with various parts of her movies, creating in this way a stream of counsciouness where her personal story is entwined with the entire story of Japan.
Moreover, the quality of animation and music is outstanding.

I can't count how many times I considered renting this and walked past it at the video store---my mistake! This movie details the life of an actress in a very surreal, dreamlike fashion. Oddly enough, all the strange loose threads tie together nicely in the end for a satisfying experience. Paprika was the gateway drug and now I'm hooked on the films of Satoshi Kon!
A complete melange of past and present with the montage technique.

God dammit Japan. For every weird as hell, over the top, bizarre, and just flat out stupid movie you crank out....you have to go and make one like this. I laughed. I cried. I stated cliches. But in the end, this has to be one of the absolute best animes I have ever seen, bar none.

Satoshi Kon's love letter to Japanese cinema, and also to Setsuko Hara, arguably the legendary Japanese actress ever, is not the most conventional animated movie. But that's what we expected from Kon's work whenever we saw them. 

A documentary crew decide to find a reclusive legendary Japanese actress and interview her about her work. The interviewer is a huge fan, and the film is told through his eyes. While she talks about her personal life and film life, the film mixes between old film scenes with a few surprising changes in between, all coming full circle by the end. And the key? The MacGuffin? What is it for? Pretty easy to guess that one before the movie ends...
Satoshi Kon at his best
yet another good anime
A beautiful movie. Twists and turns are presented with surreal transitions, yet the emotions are heart-felt. Worth watching even just to see the director's way of story-telling.
visually stunning, but also something to emotionally connect with
